What a great place to go for the best pancakes ever ....... There was a line outside of the restaurant, don't be intimidated it moves fast , the restaurant is a lot bigger then it looks !   Bring CASH , no credit cards taken !  Ice cream on pancakes is a huge hit at least with my kids !!!!

Oh my Lord, y'all. This place is all around fantastic. There's a reason famous people come here to eat. AMAZING food, INCREDIBLE service, and that small time diner feel with food that surpassed expectations. Before I talk about food, I have to mention the management. My dad grew up here, and when we came to eat here in November (we were visiting from Texas) they were already closed. Well the owner was outside and she heard we had friends that liked this place, she let us in and fed us a HUGE meal for a perfect price. We were the only ones in the diner but she made us feel so welcome. She was so nice and easy to talk to. It was really cool. The portions here are huge so come in hungry! Their French Toast and I believe other bread items on the menu are from Mancini's bread shop next door, which is the best Italian bread ever, so the French Toast was literally THE BEST French Toast I've ever had. That's saying a lot because I love french toast and try it at every breakfast place I go to. I still have dreams about it.  I can't wait to visit The Strip again and come to Deluca's for a huge meal at a great price surrounded by friendly, caring people. Great experience all around.

I was very excited when I saw Delucas was opening in Robinson as I am always anxious for a delicious non-chain venue.  Two weeks ago my family went to DeLucas for breakfast.  We arrived at 830 am and beat the crowd.  Service was awful!  We waited 15 minutes before we asked what we wanted to drink.  We finally order and the food comes out staggered.  My two sons get their meals (pancakes) and my wife and I wait a few more minutes for ours.  Most of her meal comes (no bread which was needed for the eggs), and my pancakes were no where to be found.  The remainder of our food finally comes to our table.

Bottom line service was awful.  Food was ok.  I will not rush back and will go out of my way to get to Pamela's for breakfast!
Crowded...old school vibe...good food and value

I think this place is just hyped up way too much. The food was average, or even below average greasy diner food. We were seated under the air conditioner so were freezing the entire time we were there. I don't mind a kind of grungy diner, but this place seems sticky and gross.

Our server was very pleasant, and the woman she was training was helpful and kept up with coffee re-fills.

In all honesty, I don't know why people line-up to get breakfast from this joint. Nothing spectacular on the menu in m y opinion.... 

Second story (from my husband so I know its true).... he went there door-busting Sunday morning, after a long night out. Although they were the first people waiting at the door, and were there about 20 minutes before they opened, another group of people strolled up in front of them right at opening and were seated first. These people were then served first, and it took almost 45 minutes for my husband and his group of friends to get their food. They are guessing the group that cavalierly cut in front of them was a group of regulars. One of the people in my husbands group complained to management and they were given a gift certificate, but it almost made one of the group members late miss their flight out of town.... 

So glad we went during the week when it wasn't that crowded.

This place is amazing for breakfast! I came here with a party of five, there's a line out the door but it is well worth the wait! We were greeted and seated by a waitress who could not have been friendlier! She was sassy, energetic and fun to engage with. 

We ordered an assortment of pancakes, waffles, eggs, and more by let me leave you the highlights; Italian toast, waffle sundae, hash browns, and chocolate milkshake. These items were all to die for. 

It's a bit crowded inside, and fairly loud, but you will not regret making his your breakfast destination.

I know everyone loves DeLuca's, but the food isn't super great, and the wait is always too long. Also, the  time I have been there bathrooms almost never have soap, and if the bathrooms don't have soap, the servers and cooks aren't washing their hands. Just consider that.

Omg!! Adam Richman was right!! This place is delicious!!
Bring cash (they don't take check or card) and prepare to wait.  But the wait is sooooooo worth it!!

Since I was on a diet, I got the Bodybuilders breakfast--oatmeal(creamiest, tastiest oats I have ever eaten), fruit cup, turkey sausages (6 links), 6 scrambled egg whites, and tomato slices.  

My hubby got the New Yorker omelet which had cheese, salami, capicola (deliciously spicy) and ham.

Father in law got the Seafood omelet (lobster, crab, and shrimp topped with a savory sauce and avocado) His breakfast was the best at the table!!  Hands Down!! We were all jealous.  

To round out the meal, we absolutely had to get a pancake sundae!  We opted for the Reece.  It had chocolate chip pancakes, chocolate peanut butter ice cream, chocolate sauce, caramel sauce , whipped cream and a cherry.  Heavenly!!

I will need to return soon!

Heard about it as a staple of Pittsburgh

Got the South of the border omelette, wasn't bad, decent flavor but nothing amazing, chorizo was nice and large potions, home fries were weak, not much seasoning

We also got the seafood Benedict, not bad, good hollandaise but again nothing amazing

Overall, good service, good portions, good price, worth exploring and it was on man vs food haha, but basically your solid diner situation

Just, yum.  I pride myself on having eaten breakfast at most hole-in-the-wall spots in Pittsburgh (Pamela's, Square cafe, Coca cafe, Randall's, and quite a few places that I can't even remember the names of), but this place is my favorite.  I got the eggs bene, which was bomb, and the service was fast and it was all really cheap.  Good coffee, too.  

It's definitely divey, and if you're the type of person who typically brunches in Shadyside, it's probably not for you.

Awesome food. Awesome service. 
Just had the Country Fried Chicken & Eggs. Very good!

My friend and decided to eat at Roland's in the Strip District and thought why not go for their "famous lobster rolls" I was surprised how much YUMMY lobster was in the sandwich!   it's a definite must stop!

Went here because a friend who lives in Pittsburg said that this is a very popular place for breakfast. 

Had the pierogi breakfast with eggs--very ordinary. I wouldn't order this again. Can't understand why people would line up to dine here. 

After we left the restaurant, my friend and I smelled like a kitchen. Definitely I would not return. The smell was really strong. Had to change my clothes before continuing my day.

We are here on Sunday of Memorial Day weekend after reading positive reviews. There was a 20 minute wait, but it was certainly well worth it. I got the ham steak, eggs and potatoes. The ham steak was huge with a wonderful flavor and the potatoes were outstanding. It was one of the best breakfasts I've had in a long time. The others in my party were equally happy with their choices. Due to the large serving sizes, I'm sure we'll be good until supper time. Highly, highly recommend this Pittsburgh jewel.

Worst breakfast experience of my life.  we waited 30 minutes for a table while other tables and seats at the bar were empty.  upon asking about the empty tables the hostess gave us attitude and said they aren't ready.  when we finally sat down and ordered it took 30 more minutes to get our food.  halfway through my typical greasy diner omelet i realized our orders had been mixed up and i had been given my friends chorizo omelet in lieu of my veggie fritatta (which was really a veggie omelet).  when informing our server she told us it was our fault that we couldn't tell and its not her job to know which food goes where.  then proceeded to tell us not to come back.  when we asked for the manager we were given more attitude and eventually resulting in a yelling match with the server and manager.

worst customer service i have EVER EVER experienced.  and really the food isn't special at all.

Huge portions. That's the first thing that comes to my mind. They have a huge variety of food as well which is great for someone who's not that big into standard breakfast fare. The quality and taste of the food is not as good as it should be for the amount of time you will spend standing in line waiting for a table on a Saturday or Sunday at breakfast/brunch time. It's cool to watch the line cooks make your food, but it's almost stressful to watch the servers and cooks running around, yelling orders, and wiping sweat off their brows. Don't sit at the bar during a breakfast rush if you expect to have a relaxing meal.

There's always a line for this place, no matter what day of the week. I came here on a Friday morning for brunch, and there was a good 15-minute wait before we were seated. I must say they did a great job with getting people in and out pretty quickly. The menu was a bit messy though. They tried to make it look more fun, but I thought it was just confusing. 

After orienting myself to the menu, I decided to settle for the Californian omelet with chipotle pesto chicken, asiago cheese, spinach and avocado. The omelet came with two slices of toast. The omelet was just ok. I didn't think it was anything special. They were pretty stingy on the avocado. There wasn't enough sauce and the chicken was dried. Honestly, I didn't think the omelet was worth $12. The side of homemade fries was super plain. The Lyonnais potato at Pamela's is so much more flavorful. My dinning companion ordered the apple cinnamon bun pancake sundae. It looked delicious when it came out with a huge scoop of ice cream on top. The ice cream melted fast and left a giant puddle on the pancakes. The pancakes were delicious, but the sogginess from the melted ice cream really ruined it. It was good the first few bites, but not something I can finish. 

Overall, I had a good dinning experience at Deluca's, but I did not think this place is worth all the hype. Though, I'm willing to come back and try something else on the menu, hoping maybe I ordered all the wrong stuff the first time.

I had a mixed grill (was feeling particularly carnivorous that day) and it was good.  Loads of meat, served with grilled veggies and potatoes.  I couldn't finish it, and ended up taking some home, and it proceeded to be my breakfast for two days after that.  

The breakfast meats are pretty good, and the prices are good too.  Standard diner fare, with a little more of a busy atmosphere.

I personally think that this place is pretty overrated.  I've gone a several times, and I'm never satisfied.  Maybe I'm just not a fan of super greasy and unoriginal breakfasts?  Not my top pick in the city by any means.  Also, it's ridiculous how busy this place gets for what they offer.  And it feels dirty.  So I'll go elsewhere.

I went there last weekend with one of my Bestfriends and it was truly amazing!!! I have been craving it all week.. Everything from the delicious chocolate chip pancakes to the coffee!! My biggest pet peeves is having terrible "fake" breakfast food but this did not dissapoint. The eggs were real, not the mediocre egg beaters and the crispy bacon wasn't too greasy or fatty. I cannot wait to go back! Truly great food and great service

Our server Norma was excellent. They also have an extensive menu which can be good if you have perfected it all. We ordered the chicken and waffles had a side of bacon and a side of avocado. The coffee and orange juice were delicious and we enjoyed the free coffee refills. The food was expected of diner food but not of one that is a famous location. The chicken and waffles were too pricey for the taste and size. We are glad we can say we went there but will not go back again.

Deluca's just gets me. I am not fancy and always hungry. Deluca's is not fancy and always gives me enough food for the next 3 days.

Deluca's is located right in the middle of the strip district in Pittsburgh. They perfectly embody the Steel City with the older and interior and hearty offerings. I've never had a bad meal here. I'm not a big sweets person, but I have taken large bites of my sister's chocolate chip pancakes. They're absolutely delicious, and enough to feed the whole family. However, I am a savory omelette type of morning gal. I've had both the Super Bowl and the Seafood omelettes, and they're amazing. I especially love the seafood omelette because for $13.99, you receive an omelette the size of a newborn child and it is STUFFED with seafood. It is such a good deal! Besides the omelettes, my favorite item is the seafood Benedict. Their hollandaise sauce is incredible and of course, you have a solid 3-4 meals out of it.

Ugh, I'm sad I won't get my Deluca's fix until next month. If you're in Pittsburgh and have some cash (no cards!), definitely stop by. It's worth the hype.

We were walking to another restaurant for breakfast on Saturday morning when we happened upon this place and the large line out front.  It's located in the heart of the Strip District, so there was a ton going on the day we ate here. The food is very good and the portions are huge. I'd recommend going early to avoid the long waits. And note that they only accept cash, no credit cards.

Loved Deluca's!  We came here for breakfast after spending the night in PGH for a Pirates game.  I've given up on finding a diner in Youngstown so it was nice to visit one here!  Our waitress greeted us as we came in the door and we had coffee in front of us within second of our butts hitting our seats!  Omelettes were made with freshly cracked eggs and were huge!  I had the Western and the hubby had a Greek with chicken.  Both were very good as were the home fries.  They have several different egg benedict choices that all looked great as did a huge pancake special that the person sitting next to us had.

Makes me want to drive down from Youngstown on Saturday for breakfast!  The hour drive each way would be well worth it!

The chicken and waffle is awesome ! Delicious breaded fried chicken breast on top of a fluffy waffle.  The fried chicken is salty and savory along with the sweet waffle powdered sugar sprinkled on top.  Pour on some sweet syrup and a little hot sauce supplied on the table already.  It was great really hit the spot.  It also came with 2 eggs whatever style you want - I got sunny side up and dipped my chicken and waffle in the egg yolk :-) FYI the place is cash only

Great place great food if you don't mind waiting a little bit outside until some room clears out to be a seated its a small place but some of the greatest breakfast food in town the service is very very quick. We went on NYE and it was 10 degrees but it was worth the wait for cheap great food! The breakfast is the best I highly recommend The chicken and biscuits! Big portions of food The staff is very nice felt very welcomed! So if you're in the strip district I highly recommend!

Wow... wow... one of the best breakfasts I've had in a while. There's a good amount of parking around, especially if you get there early.... and you'll want to get there early, because there's a FREAKING LINE OUT THE DOOR TO GET SEATED!! So worth it, though. Everything is yummy.

Love Delucas! I got the Nutella french toast, which was basically just slabs of Nutella spread on regular french toast....meets the requirements but for all the hype surrounding Delucas I was expecting a bit more on that end. It was pretty tasty, though I prefer the french toast at Micro Diner in Mt Washington. The waiter was very friendly, and the place is adorable. I'll definitely be coming back!

I wanted to come here since I had good experiences at the one in the strip but omg. Not the same. It was packed so my mom and I sat at the bar. I ordered the chicken finger basket. When I got my food, the chicken fingers were burnt and the fries were undercooked. They forgot to put my moms order in so she had to watch me eat until she finally got hers. Our waitress was MIA so someone else had to cash us out. Other waitresses were overheard loudly complaining and cussing. Horrible dining experience.
Everything was delicious! Had the breakfast burrito and the wife had the hot roast beef sandwich with mounds of mashed potatoes.  Soo much food!

Went this morning with my girlfriend and we got almost the same thing. The home fries where just a little under cooked but everything else we had was great. The pancakes where amazing and the food came out lightning fast.

I thought it was good food for sure but it was slightly over priced. I think you can get the same quality food for a cheaper price and half the wait time. I think its over hyped but still worth a visit once in your life.

Quick, rough, greasy, cash only and not bad. An old school greasy diner with a truck stop mentality. Whatever image that conjures in your mind is probably what you can expect.

Food's alright. I liked it and I'd eat here again. It does get crowded, but I wouldn't wait outside for a seat to eat here.

Found this on yelp and it was worth the visit.  Super fast friendly service.  The food is fantastic!   I had the eggs Benedict and the hollandaise was perfect .  Hubby had the corned beef hash and was equally happy with his meal. Highly recommend for breakfast!

Awful service... food is just ok.
Not worth standing in line... Plus they only take cash...

Both times I've eaten breakfast here, I was extremely, extremely pleased. However, I think the food was better my first visit compared to the second, and I'm not one to branch out at breakfast places, so this is a fair comparison of the exact same sandwich, service, and company. 

Each visit we waited in line outside of Deluca's for a table. It was raining, but the line moved quickly and we were under cover anyways. The service is prompt and friendly. 

It's definitely a great place to recommend to out of towners for a good local breakfast stop. The bread is all Mancini's...delicious. Local flavor, great location. Will return.

Whoa! This place takes breakfast and goes to town with it. Awesome old school diner in Pittsburgh's Strip District. You walk inside and its like stepping back into the 1950s. Personable waitresses abound there to greet you. You can sit at the old fashioned counter or grab a booth. They have a pretty elaborate menu that offers breakfast and lunch but the breakfast is what you're here for. I ordered the Bionic Omelette not really realizing what I was getting myself into. This thing was mammoth and has practically everything in it you would eat for breakfast. Bacon, fresh sausage, onions, hash browns and more! After this meal I ate nothing else for the whole day. I was eating off of this thing for three days and believe me when I say I have a big appetite so that tells you how big it is. The coolest thing about eating here was watching the guy behind the counter cook the meal on the big fryer like someone cooking a homemade breakfast at home in their kitchen. Food comes out pretty fast and prices are okay. The bionic omelette was $13 and like I said it fed me for a few days. You can't miss this place if you're looking for it because its the place with the giant rooster on the roof. Also, theres a booth here marked where Tom Cruise sat during filming the movie Jack Reacher.

Came here today for breakfast. Definitely a bit of a wait to get a table but the food was good. Large portions good food- I got the Reese's Cup hot cakes and they were good until the end when the pancakes soaked up all of the ice cream and got a little too rich. Other than that I was a fan of them.

The apple crepes looked really good as well and are something I would go back to get.

I liked it and would return for sure but at the same time I would put it at just under 5 stars

I'm always looking for local hole-in-the-walls places that have a feel for the city, people, and culture. Places where the atmosphere is full of history and of course the food is good! This place was both. Nothing glamorous at all but that's why I liked it. I took my family for breakfast and it was a quick and great meal. My daughter and I had the biscuits and gravy and my wife has the veggie breakfast. We all agreed that the food was great! If I had any negatives at all it would be that the temperature was hot inside and the booths are very small, which in my opinion is worth it for the experience. The waitress was pleasant, quick, and helpful. If you are in Pittsburgh and looking for a great breakfast and experience, go here!

Came here with a group of 6, plus a toddler, midmorning on a Thursday. No wait! The service was EXCELLENT. Quick, friendly, efficient. They anticipated our every need. The inside was larger than you would think as mentioned in several reviews here. Overall I had a great experience. We had probably every breakfast item you could think of at our table (crepes, french toast, pancakes, danish pancakes, eggs, mixed grill, sides of meat) as we went a little crazy with our order, but in particular, I ordered the nutella banana crepe and it was DELICIOUS. It had a whole banana inside! While that was definitely a decadent dish, my fiance ordered the mixed grill which was very healthy and fresh tasting. I would go back!

Another Pittsburgh legend . Always voted "best breakfast in the burgh  " and I have to agree . I like the unusual breakfast combinations . Who can't refuse ice cream on your pancakes in the middle of a hot July ???
Love Deluca's Eggs Benedict! Crazy busy place, but if you're willing to sit at the counter in the back, you can get seated pretty quickly.  Cash only.

This place is one of the Pittsburgh classic breakfast spots, located in the strip district area, there are often lines out the door on the weekends, much of the hype on this place inevitably leads to this, so unless your up early and out and about, expect to wait if you have a group of people. Also, it should be noted, it's kinda touristsy , by that I mean actual tourists, and weekend tourists in from the suburban cultural wastelands for a authentic Pittsburgh breakfast, like their parents ate, or some such nonsense, so that also means it's pricey for the straight off the Sysco truck food that it is. 
I'm giving this place 5 stars based solely on the absolute ticket slayers that are on open display on the short order line set up they have there, these men are a joy to watch, and the speed at which they got the orders out was honestly pretty impressive, hats off to these cooks!   Total bad asses!!!! That, and the waitress was really nice too!

Whenever I visit a city that I haven't been to before, I insist on eating at a place that is true to the character of that city.  After my visit to Deluca's, I have no hesitation in claiming that this restaurant is Pittsburgh at its finest.  This efficient and popular greasy-spoon joint serves up hearty meals at a decent price.  

They claim to offer the "best breakfast in town," and I wouldn't argue with that statement...nor would the millions of other people who waited 30+ minutes to even get into the restaurant on the cold, wet, and snowy Saturday morning I went.  I ordered the seasonal pumpkin pancake special, and I was pleasantly surprised that they gave me the option of ordering kielbasa as the side meat instead of just the usual ham or breakfast sausage.

I almost feel bad giving this place just 4 stars because I really liked it.  But alas, it just wasn't my favorite type of food, and as much as the long wait and cash-only policy is characteristic of this diner-style restaurant, it wasn't exactly pleasant.  Beware that if you come during a busy time with a large group (5+ people), expect to wait a bit longer than smaller groups.

We're in the Pittsburgh area visiting from out of town and spotted this place in a sea of chain restaurants and decided to give it a go. Despite our high hopes, the food really fell flat. We were in for lunch and none of us left pleased with our meal, but I will say their breakfast menu looked great - maybe we should have ordered that.

I was seated at the counter immediately. Coffee arrived quickly and my order was taken as soon as I put the menu down . Omelet was large and tasty. Home fries were plentiful. Sever kept my coffee cup full.  Did notice a person at the counter for five minutes that never received attention. He got up and left as I would have.

quick service even when really busy. Huge proportions. Good prices. Lots of menu items and variety to pick from- not just breakfast. the Superbowl omelette is really great and highly recommend it. Friendly staff too.
Califonia Benedict was probably the best breakfast I've ever had.  They place is clean and the service is good. My coffee was never empty.

Picture it: Sicily.  1924.  A young peasant girl with some lire and a dream takes her place in line at a humble trattoria run by fellow paisan, signore DeLuca.

Wait, wait.  I got "Golden Girls" mixed up with Yelp.

Picture it: Pittsburgh.  2013.  A [ahem] young couple with some cash and a dream take their place in line at a humble diner run by........someone.  Probably no longer related to the original DeLuca.  At any rate, they were prepared for a long wait; had just hunkered down to weather the blowhard frat type behind them bellowing into his iPhone about the difference between a wine and beer hangover and repeatedly declaring his determination to see what waiting in line for breakfast was all about; when the angel of breakfast mercy, a rotund little bespectacled woman, called out for two people willing to sit at the counter.

Counter, you say?  This particular couple *loves* counter-sitting at greasy spoons, watching short order cooks literally sling hash, fry eggs and flip flapjacks with deft precision and enviable speed.  And so the counter is exactly where they landed this Saturday morning, entranced by the choreography behind it, ignoring the sticky Linoleum floors.  He had Chicken and Waffles -- buckwheat waffle, to be exact -- she the Cinnamon Bun Pancakes.  And, oh.  They were both so happy.  Crisped, crunchy white meat chicken atop a flavorful and toothsome waffle, dusted with powdered sugar and drizzled with syrup; cinnamon-studded hotcakes with swirls of icing and swaths of maple syrup.  Washed down by the requisite *okay* drip coffee.  Served by a manager with his finger on the pulse of every server, line cook and bus boy in the joint.

Cash only, dear reader.

[15 Minutes of Fame: "Man v. Food: Pittsburgh"]

There is a line at the door on Saturday mornings, but it moves quickly.  If possible, sit at the counter to watch the frenetic activity at the grill.

The portions are huge and the quality very good.  We enjoyed the ranchero omelet and the French toast with blueberries.

Fun spot to people watch activities on the strip and people watch people inside the diner. Great greasy spoon right on the strip. The french toast made with Mancini's raisin bread was really good. DH had omelette with chorizo and reports that it was pretty spicy. Homefries, which we requested to be extra crispy, were perfect.

The flavors are bursting, and the home fries are truly well made. Pancakes r crispy on the inside and battery, yummy on the inside. I got the California Benedict- ontop of Italian toast, topped with avocado, tomato, spinach, and Asiago cheese. The veggies were extremely fresh and tasted local (maybe it's in my mind) and the hollandaise sauce blended well with the home fries on the side. Ketchup not even needed. Extremely fast and efficient service. The man knew what he was doing.. Didn't let our coffees go empty. You will leave feeling sedated by the heat of the cooking indoors and a happy full belly. Lots to walk around outdoors to walk it off. We will be returning!

This place is amazing.  I need to get my pictures of my food on here.  I love it and I will wait however long to sit here and enjoy their delicious breakfast (which is the only thing I have ever had).  Love it.

After stopping in Pittsburgh during a road trip, I was starving for some grub. I searched my trusty yelp app and discovered Deluca's. I remembered the name and place from an episode of Diners, Drive-Ins & Dives and jumped at the chance to try some food because Guy Fieri knows his ISH!

SO its in a strip mall, weird i know. Its kind of hidden, not a huge sign to say Delucas but nevertheless we got there.

Its a diner true and true. Red bar stools, black and white checkered floors, all the retro diner decor. I loved it!

So my husband got the MOAB or "Mother of all burritos"...PACKED to the brim with onions, eggs, sausage, bacon chorizo breakfast potatoes, you name it. It was the size of his head im not even exaggerating. It was so flavorful. for $9?! SCORE!!!!

I got a chicken fingers basket because i was craving fries. I was kind of upset because they serve shoestring fries and i didnt get what i wanted out of it. The chicken fingers were hand breaded and you can definetly tell the difference. They arent frozen and are steaming hot and fresh!!

I give this place 3 stars because the service was HORRIBLE. Our waitress was like 80, you could tell she didnt want to be bothered  let alone do her job. She moped around, got us our drinks took our order and never came back. The she just handed the receipt to us without even asking if we wanted dessert or anything else. Like shoo'ing us away.

The lobster bisque was amazing.  The Super Bowl omelet was different but a definite touchdown.  I would have never thought mashed potatoes would work so well in an omelet. i Would have given 5 stars if they used a list like Pamela's instead of standing in line.

I finally visited this place.  I, however, did not order the famous breakfast pancakes with ice cream and whipped topping.  Instead, I got a fish sandwich and fries.  My friends ordered breakfast and they said it was delicious.  The fish sandwich was good.  It was what I expected.  The water tasted terrible.

The restaurant was extremely busy.  It took us at least a half hour or more to get in the door.  Every employee was running around like crazy and the kitchen floor was covered in food.  It was so busy that there was no time for them to clean.  

The seating is cramped and there really is no ambiance.  I recommend ordering the pancakes featured on Man vs. Food to experience what the place is famous for.  

The low score is due to the wait-time, cramped feeling when entering and sitting down at a table, and the overall craziness all around you while eating.

I don't really have the urge to return unless there is no line to get in.

I always enjoy my visits to pittsburgh. I was especially excited to visit after finding out there was a great place for breakfast that was on the travel network (man vs. food). I am a true food lover and Food Network and Travel Channel must really love pittsburgh. They are always on man vs food and diners, drive ins and dives. 
I found out the hard way that just because you are showcased on a dandy show doesn't mean your food is up to par. 
Just to make it very clear I am a southerner. I did however go to delucas with my girlfriend who was born and raised in pittsburgh and surrounding suburbs. So I was able to look past the brash attitude of the person at the register yelling at my girlfriend instead of seating us. She however was pretty turned off by it. 
There wasn't a wait. We got seated pretty quickly after my girlfriend had to let the lady know we were there well before the ambush of people that poured in after we arrived. (that's when my girlfriend got yelled at) 
After being seated I was really excited about the food. The place was hoppin and the coffee was really good. The menu had a huge list of things to choose from. I thought it was going to be a great place. I had really high hopes.
The server we had was ok. Not very friendly but efficient. She was the shorter of the two I saw. We kind of wished we had the tall girl. She seemed a lot more friendly. 
We didn't wait too long to get our food but when we got it you would have thought it would have taken a couple hours. I got the biscuits and gravy (one of my favorite breakfast foods) and potatoes. They were both stone cold. The gravy on the biscuits was more like a soup and the potatoes were well cold. I really couldn't get passed the fact that my food was cold. 
My girlfriend got the california omelette with potatos and fruit with the Italian toast. She like the fruit and toast but that was it. I almost choked on my sausage gravy when I saw her omelette. It was practically black. I know sometimes people over cook eggs. It's not cool but it happens. How do you even send eggs out that are practically black. I guess at least it was hot. Her potatoes needless to say were also cold.
I was really looking forward to eating at a delicious breakfast place in pittsburgh. I was disappointed.

My favorite breakfast dish would be anything with poached eggs and some kind of sauce on it. I continue to visit Delucas because they have been able to perfectly poach every single egg I've ever had there. EVERY. SINGLE. EGG. They are seriously never overdone and are perfect. PERFECT. 

I've only had eggs Benedict type breakfast plates and shakes there, but I've been with others who have tried different options. Everything else was described as "good, typical breakfast food."

Sometimes there is a wait (especially on weekends), but service is usually pretty quick and generally pretty good. They aren't the nicest or friendliest servers. They're not rude, and they are good at their jobs. They typically won't sit at your table and chat, but they are quick and usually don't mess anything up. 

If you like a lot of different options for breakfast food, Delucas is the place to go.

It is what it is. The original Pittsburgh greasy spoon. No frills here just good old fashioned GRUB. you cannot go wrong with anything. Coffee quickly served. Staff always friendly. Always a crowd. Be patient, take it all in, every walk of Pittsburgh life eats here.

Well, I finally caved.  After years of resisting that persistent, daunting line that has become a rite of Pittsburgh passage, I finally braved the wait and went to Deluca's.

Perhaps it was due to good company (or the first signs of sun this spring), but the 30+ minute wait that we endured seemed to go relatively quick.  After finally making it to the doorway, we were asked to come in by the hostess, only to be left inside the doorway with no real inclination of whether we should proceed to one of the several open tables or wait.  When we finally tracked down the hostess again, she said we needed us to wait to sit down as to, "not upset the chef."

Fast forward, and we've finally sat down (in the seat Tom Cruise filmed Jack Reacher nonetheless).  After attempting the scan the entirely too complex menu (do you really need multiple versions of what is essentially the same dish?), we settled on the breakfast burrito, the seafood benedict, the seafood omelette (same as the seafood benedict, just with the bread on the side instead of under) and the apple pancake sundae (figured go big or go home).

Within about fifteen minutes, the burrito, benedict and omelette were brought out.   By this point, out entire party was starving and I told everyone to go ahead and get started (the server said my pancakes would be another minute).  Overall, each were about the most stereo-typically bland diner food you could ever get.  But, fast forward twenty minutes...  still no pancakes (and everyone else has finished).

Once the server finally made it back around, she mentioned something in passing about the apples on the pancake and left again (we had no idea what she said).  After another five minutes or so, my pancakes finally came out, and by this point, ready to leave, I succumbed to hunger and dove in.

Bland... bland... bland... and an associated stomach ache from the pure sugar rush.  After chewing through about half the plate, I gave up on it (I almost never leave food on the plate).  Ready to go, we asked for the check, with the one saving grace that redeemed Deluca's from one star being the server proactively taking the pancakes off of our tab.

Check this off the list as a one and done.

Love this place omg! Just wish it wasn't always so crowded. The prices are cheap and you get PLENTY of food for the price. Waiters are usually friendly when I come in so that's not an issue, only issue is parking. The strip district is always busy. It's worth the parking hassle!! :)
This is a classic diner: a little dingy, the service was kind of rushed, and the food is alright. The prices are decent for what you get. I'm not sure we'd come back here.

We stayed in downtown Pittsburgh to get the full city experience. This place was supposed to have the best breakfast, but I didn't find anything special about it. I got the Italian Vegetarian Fritatta. Some of the veggies were cooked okay, but the onions were not. They ruined the dish by the bitter flavor (which I have found are usually reflective of 'old' onions). Others had the full stack of pancakes, blueberry french toast, raspberry crepes, and kid's chocolate chip pancakes.nothing really amazing there either. Nobody finished their food. That is either because they gave us a lot (in most cases) or the person did not like it enough to over stuff themselves to finish it. We ended up leaving with lots of leftovers, and my son who wasn't with us when we went enjoyed eating them. But he also is a very hungry teenager with a large appetite :).

Also only takes cash. No checks or credit.

Great place for local flavor! This is a wonderful place if you are looking for a great taste of Pittsburgh. You will stand in line to get a table but it is well worth the wait. 


Don't miss the chicken and waffles!

I believe we got there after their rush because the floor was totally trashed.  Although the employees were great about clearing off the tables, they certainly could have taken a broom to the floor; especially since at this point there were only several tables ever occupied while we were there.

Anyhow, I had an omelet with avocado & Asiago.  While the taste was good, I personally prefer a fluffy omelet, whereas theirs are overcooked a bit with a slight brown "burn" to it.  It makes it a bit dry.  Hubby had eggs, ham & pancakes.  He told me how good their ham is and he was right!  Absolutely delicious.  Of course I tried his pancake, too.  Nothing out out of the ordinary, but still good.

Prices are kind of high if you ask me.  Better rating if you would learn to keep the establishment alot cleaner.

The best french toast in the city. Small, french bread slices soaked in egg, and hit with just the right amount of butter.

Deluca's inside is filthy. They know it, and they love it. The hours are weird, though they're open into the mid-afternoon. I liked Deluca's UNTIL I discovered JoJo's, which is nearby, but closes at noon. Now, Deluca's feels second rate, because I'm an eggs, meat, and potatoes person more than a griddle dude.

If it was the other way around, Deluca's might be my favorite.

Food was great. Service was quick. Very, very busy place. We waiting in line outside for about 20 mins before we could get a seat. It moved pretty fast and they get tables turned quickly. We both had eggs and bacon with homefries. I also had pancakes. All the food was good for diner food.

This is my go-to breakfast joint in Pittsburgh, especially since it's open super early so I can stop by after getting off night shift. Their menu is huge. Whatever you're craving, they have it! I usually go for one of their eggs benedict dishes or an omelette. Prices are low and portions are huge! It is a really popular place so there's almost always a wait, but once you sit down and order your food comes out unbelievably quickly. Parking can be tough sometimes.

Love this greasy-spoon spot in its original instantiation down in the strip, and I love it out in Robinson. Friendly service, short-order food (we had four of us, including two kids, out). They didn't charge extra for hot chocolate refills, and that's a winner in my book. I ate fried eggs, sausage, pancakes, and had coffee, and I loved it all - but diner food is sorta my thing. I love it as long as it ain't bad, and this was good.

There was a mistake on one of the ordered meals, and the server took the plate away (for good) saying she'd adjust the tab, but then she took off maybe $2 rather than the cost of the meal we didn't eat or take with us. I wasn't the one paying the bill, and this fact was confusing to the point at which I didn't understand that's what she did until it wasn't worth going back to address. (If you take someone's mostly-full plate without offering a replacement, you gotta take that whole order off the tab...).

Apart from that oddity and some wet silverware, the meal was priced reasonably and the food was good - I'd surely go back.

Delucas,

the iconic Pittsburgh breakfast spot in the strip. People rave about this place and Pamelas, and to both i wonder why? 

I see lines of people waiting outside of Deluca's and I wonder how many of these are returning customers or people just inspired by the novelty.

This is not to say its bad, but it IS overrated.

My better half and I both arrived with starving appetites, and the portions were very generous. I give them kudos for prompt service in the malestrom of customers. The menu options are diverse and unique. Perhaps if I try more I could revamp my opinion.

I ordered a concoction of fried chicken, gravy, home fries and scrambled eggs. It was greasy and tasty, but maybe my expectations were too high? Perhaps I have also been spoiled by similar food elsewhere in Pittsburgh that remains off the beaten path and for half the price. Thanks Delucas, it was fun, but its me...not you. We can still be friends right?

I really enjoyed my breakfast at Deluca's!  I was visiting a good friend in Pittsburgh about two weeks ago, and she insisted that we go to Deluca's before hitting an arts festival and Pride.

First of all, our waitress was fantastic.  She was patient with me being overwhelmed by the extensive menu, and she was on top of everything when it came to keeping us good and caffeinated.

I ordered the Huevos Rancheros, while my friend got the Breakfast of Champs with chocolate chip pancakes.  The Huevos Rancheros were great, the Spanish sauce was kinda sweet and very unique.  It was fantastic!  My friend's breakfast was HUGE, and those pancakes were perfect.

Loved the spot, the diner was super charming, and the service was wonderful.  I'd definitely go back again!

No Stiller's tickets this past Sunday so waited till near game time to visit.  Shortest line I have ever seen.  Food and atmosphere are pure Pittsburgh.   Our group had Steel City breakfast, waffles, pancakes, and french toast.  Huge portions and delicious on top of that.  The "Baltimore Blows" shirts worn by many wait staff were perfect.

Great breakfast place in the city.  It's best to try to get here early on the weekends or come on the weekdays due to all of the regulars and tourists on the weekends. They have huge portions for a reasonable price.  It is your typical "no frills" diner but that is the beauty of it.  I really enjoy the California benedict.

Waiter was excellent
Coffee was terrible, pancakes were just ok
Specialty breakfast was ok as well

I feel like my experiences here have been a miss but other customers have had hits. I'm not sure whether I just have bad luck or if my expectations for food and service are high, but I don't think I'm asking too much when all I'm looking for is quality food and attentive waiters.

The first time I came to Deluca's I ordered one of their extravagant sweet pancakes. I was so excited for it, but was incredibly disappointed when I was instead served a burnt pancake that was barely edible... I'm not sure why you would even think it's okay to serve burnt pancakes, but needless to say, I was not impressed with Deluca's since then. 

Fast forward to 2013 when I decided to give the place another try since there's always so much hype about this place. This time around, I tried the california eggs benedict. Was it hands down the most delicious eggs benedict I've ever had? Definitely not, but it was decent enough. I also ordered a strawberry banana milkshake, which was a great disappointment. I thought it tasted watery and expensive for the quality of the drink--I'm never getting that again.

There's always been a small line on Saturday mornings and they're cash only, so by no means am I itching to come back anytime soon. Also, they're always so busy that the service is subpar. Waiters are only there to grab your orders and have no interest in showing any appreciation for their customers. The wait for our check took forever as well because our server was inattentive. 

Deluca's will do the trick if you need a breakfast place to go to but I've placed it dead last on my list. I've had much better experiences and great food in other places like Pamela's and the Original Pancake House.

Went back and forth on my rating decision here. The food is certainly a five, the service a three (only somewhat fast, not particularly friendly, and expect to have to ask for refills on anything). The overall experience is in the middle as you are dealing with a ton of tasty options, a comfortable environment, a nice location for a Saturday brunch (outside of the wait and the parking challenges) and solid classic diner experience. 

The price also is only decent, and though it's a single dollar sign option many of the menu items will push closer to the upper end. I had the breakfast burrito with their special sauce and yes that sauce was special, absolutely delicious. Couldn't find the breakfast menu anywhere online, so giving that as a personal recommendation.

Worth a stop if you happen to be in the Strip.

We have only been coming here for 25 years. I had to shout out because it's been five or so since my last visit. Some things are just worth coming back to. 
Benedict on Mancinis? Absolutely!!!
Priced right and worth the wait. 
Don't forget to bring CASH.

I like!  Here's my take:

PROS:
- Food is great. Is there a better traditional breakfast in Pittsburgh?  I doubt it!
- The breakfast sandwich is my fave. Eggs, spicy sausage, and cheese on Mancini's bread. Just do it. 
- Service is very quick and efficient. Try to run out of coffee. You can't!
- The menu is huge, lots of good stuff to try. 

CONS:
- Its CASH ONLY, and it's now year 2018...  And that's all I can offer on the negative side. 

If you've had this on your list but still haven't tried it, DO IT NOW!  Then write a Yelp review!!!

I always made fun of all the people standing in line on the weekend mornings waiting to have breakfast at DeLuca's that was until I found myself waiting in that same line. I happened to be in Pittsburgh for the weekend visiting friends when it was suggested to try the place out. There had to be 30 or so people in line waiting to get into the place on a Saturday morning. It probably took 30 to 45 minutes to get to the front but the plus side is there is a coffee shop a few doors down to get something warm to drink. When we finally got it we were seated at the counter which was a fine place to sit considering you can watch all the cooks running around like crazy turning out food by the minute. There are lots of things that look good but I settled on an omelet with a bunch of vegetables and covered in three kinds of cheese that was downright awesome. My friend also had some combination of eggs and veggies which he proceeded to polish off something I could not do. We were also witness to a few people tackling the pancakes with the sundae on top. Good luck with that on early morning. I am not sure it is the best breakfast in town but it is certainly worth the wait especially if it's not too cold outside. I will be back.

No two ways about it, this is a classic old style diner.  It has been in existance since 1951.  I went on a Fri morning and they were crowded but I was able to get a seat at the counter.  I was told that it would have been much busier on a sat or sun.

There was some disagreement between two waitresses as who would take my order.  A few sharp words were spoken between them.

First thing, the menu is a novel.  It takes too long to read it.  Places that concentrate on making a few items generally do a better job at it.  

I didn't have to wait too long for my breakfast.  I ordered eggs benedict with a side of corned beef hash browns.  The eggs were cooked perfectly but the sauce was not a hollandaise and had no lemon flavor at all.  That detracted from the flavor.  

One thing to know ahead of time is that they only take cash.  No credit cards.  Apparently this is somewhat common in the Strip from what I was told.

I took my husband and kids here.  The food was ok.  My husband was disappointed and said the potatoes were gross and didn't eat them! But honestly if you go here you are going to get a good diner meal! The menu is big.  I suggest getting your standard breakfast!

Yes, Deluca's is the iconic breakfast spot in Pittsburgh and one of the few places I will wait in line for breakfast on a weekend.  In the snow.  Why?  Do you really need reasons?  Well, for one, the breakfast burrito that barely fits on the plate.  For another, the Steel City Breakfast of Champions that includes all the breakfast food staples.  Need more?  The Bionic Omelet made of 6 eggs and as many fillings.  I've taken on all of these challenges (not at once) and triumphed 2 of the 3 times.  (The Bionic Omelet's onions got the better of me and I just couldn't finish.)  And I just have to love any place that serves Mancini's Italian toast.

This place can get busy, but it runs like a machine.  Sit at the counter by the grill on a Saturday or Sunday morning and just watch in amazement at how quickly and efficiently orders are filled when there's a line out the door.  Sometimes the wait service can be a little slow.  And it is still a cash only establishment.  But it is still my go-to breakfast spot in the Strip.  The prices I sometimes feel can be a little steep, but then I see the portion size and it makes sense.  Deluca's is always, in a word, dependable.

A great breakfast place!  The place can use a make over, but I thought it was charming and you went back in time with the red and white checkered floors, and what looked liked original counter and green worn leather stools.  The staff was nice and friendly too.  I stayed at the Westin Hotel and it was about a 10 block walk (1 mile).  My husband and I shared the Steeler breakfast plate and it was one of the best breakfests we had.  It was a good thing we shared bc it came with 2 toasts, 2 (8") pancakes, 1 (5") sweet sausage, 2 slices bacon, home fries, 2 eggs.  Every item was cooked perfect and the pancakes were the best I had at a restaurant, a bit crispy and fluffy inside.   Too bad we were so full and couldn't finish the pancakes and toast.  Everything else we finished with a smile.  The portions are large.  We had 2 cups of very good coffee and the Steeler special and our bill was $12.  A bargain for all we had.  

If I ever come back to Pittsburgh, I would go there again and try more of the resturants on the Strip District.

Friendly Service and amazing food.  Great for breakfast with friends or family. Be prepared to wait if you go on a weekend.  We done on Friday at 10:30am and waited approximately 10 minutes, much quicker than the weekend.  CASH ONLY, so you know it's legit!

In town for the 3-day weekend, I wanted to try some of the more popular spots in Pittsburgh.

Since Deluca's is popular -- hey, it has been on TV! -- I expected to be disappointed.  Nope.  The menu was gigantic -- as big as the portions.

The cinnamon bun hotcakes with the warm, gooey, sweet apples, glazed pecans, and gratuitous whipped cream and vanilla ice cream?  Surprisingly great -- just a great balance of flavors and textures.

The only misfire was on the cheesesteak omelet -- it was supposed to come with a sauce.  When I mentioned it to the waiter, he thought it needed one, too -- but didn't know that it did.  Not a big deal that he didn't know -- just that it did need something.  Eh, I had the hotcakes to share anyway; there was plenty of food on the table.

I'm glad I don't live in Pittsburgh.  I'd be 50 pounds heavier.

FYI cash only.

After reading some positive reviews, we decided to venture over to the Strip District to round up some brunch at Deluca's. It seemed like the rest of the city had the same idea, but I was committed to visiting here and leaving satisfied. Done.

Yes, you'll wait for a table (and probably even wait outside), but the cooks, servers and bus boys moved very efficiently, knocking out orders for all the small booths and tables. Once we were seated, one menu item called out to me: Texas Cinnamon French Toast with eggs and bacon. Oh, and coffee, of course.

In no time at all, it was all sitting in front of me and in no time at all, it was all gone. The scrambled eggs were pretty standard, the bacon was perfectly cooked (not fatty and not burnt to a crisp) and the French toast was sweet and delicious, even without adding any syrup.

As already mentioned, the service was prompt and the prices were reasonable. However, this is a "Cash Only" spot, so keep the plastic in your wallet.

After reading the reviews about the line and wait, we got here at about 8:00 on a Saturday morning and were seated right away. The menu is extensive and I was having a hard time choosing what to get. After some thought, I went with the strawberry pancakes and scrambled eggs. Breakfast sausage came with it but that went to my husband. He ordered a breakfast sandwich, after seeing the amazing bread it came on. One thing I liked was that they were really accommodating with making things just the way you want. My husband wanted scrambled eggs on his breakfast sandwich and that wasn't a problem! Service was quick and our food arrived shortly.

My pancakes were delicious, however I was disappointed with the strawberries-they were FROZEN! Well, thawed out but a mushy, pre-frozen strawberry mess! I understand this is a diner, but I guess in June I was just expecting some fresh strawberries. The eggs were good, nothing spectacular. My husband enjoyed his breakfast sandwich but said the sausage that came with mine was tough and he didn't eat much of it. We were in and out in less than 30 minutes.

Overall, it was a decent breakfast, but I would definitely order something different if I were to return. The service was fast and friendly, but I would have been disappointed if we had waited awhile for that breakfast.

Deluca's is a great diner in the strip district! I love their eggs benedict and pancakes both are amazing! It is really fun to sit at the counter and watch them cook while you eat!! You won't be disappointed but make sure you get there early on Saturdays!

First time here and I loved it! I left planning my next visit.
The wait seemed long, but it only took about 20 minutes. Don't come here to dine and catch up with friends because the food comes out very quickly and they are constantly having people in and out. I expected that and that was exactly what I wanted. I think I was there for 20 to 30 minutes. 
I expect that everything there is amazing and can't wait to try french toast. 

Definitely go here if you are looking for GOOD, cheap food and quick service!

A very long line for lunch. Waited about 30 mins for a table. The food was good as other diners I been at. The pancakes were a bit flat then what I'm use to. The south of the border omelette was more of a egg scramble than omelette. The service was fast and the prices were good, but the line is long.

We came to Deluccas after a concert, (hangover was in full force) we heard it was a local spot and had to check it out. I'm not a huge breakfast person but my omelet was DELICIOUS. I tried to eat all of it!! When I'm back in Pittsburgh I will definitely be coming back. Our waitress was great! Speedy and funny!  Only downside was the cash only!

I love Deluca's, they are proud of their traditional breakfast and the do it well. The ingredients are always fresh, the service is excellent and the menu gives you lots of options.

Here are some things you should know:

The Strip District location is cash only, but there is a newer Robinson location that takes credit cards. There are several ATM's close by ion the Strip in case you forget.

You can make reservations 24 hours in advance for parties of 6 or more. It's a great idea, especially given the lines that often go outside the door.

Deluca's is not for everybody, it's classic diner with a great reputation and they are reluctant to change. But the food is good and it's a perennial favorite and a source of pride for many Pittsburghers.

There is a hustle and bustle to Deluca's.  It's people on their way to a game, or on their way to shop in the Strip. There's a kind of excitement here which you may not find relaxing, but it's part of Pittsburgh tradition and worth experiencing.

There some unusual ethnic dishes which are quite good, for example, a Greek omelet with Feta cheese and Spinach. Pierogies. 

I like their traditional breakfast, especially because their potatoes are always served perfect. The buckwheat pancakes are something unique as well.

Deluca's is a must for anyone who wants to fully experience Pittsburgh.

Come here for a good hearty breakfast of absurd proportions, but be prepared to wait.  if food were my only concern, I would not hesitate to say DeLuca's is one of the best breakfast joints in the 'burgh.  Alas, they have terrible coffee, and for me, that's a deal-breaker.

I genuinely do not understand the hype about this place. I'm all for waiting in line for 30-45 minutes if the place is "worth the wait", but sadly this is not the case. 

My family of 5 was split into two tables, we were told they were not allowed to seat 5 people in a booth, even though we voiced our preference was to be together. That's fine, everyone has rules. Their entire back section was reserved for a party of 20, which was expected to show up about 10 minutes after our arrival. This party of 20 never showed up and the diner staff never offered that we be moved to those tables where we would've been able to sit altogether. Minor detail, but it would've been greatly appreciated. 

When I ordered my breakfast, I paused waiting for the waitress to ask me how I like my eggs, bacon or sausage, etc. When I paused, she snapped back and said, "You have to tell me how you want your eggs." It was so short & so rude. 

The food was subpar, it was at least cheap but so was the quality. 

These instances are small in nature, but they were not countered with any redeeming qualities. All in all, this place was not worth it: the line was long, the service was horrific, and the food was terrible. After years working in hospitality, I tend to be pretty lenient and understanding of the different struggles that go into a restaurant. This place does not deserve leniency or your time.
Had the seafood omelette, it was great. Sat at the diner and the waitress was very friendly & nice. Refilled my coffee promptly. I would definitely return for breakfast again.

The crepes and the omelette are simply delicious. I tried the newyorker omelette and pecan banana crepe and they both are awesome. Large portion size and extremely satisfying. The service is very prompt and the place is buzzing!!!!!!. Coffee is a little below par, but the bread from local bakery is very fresh. The reason I docked one point was for the wait time and they only accept cash.

My dad and I went to deluca's for breakfast while we were in Pittsburgh. We had heard that deluca's was very good, we also heard that it was always hard to get a seat. When we got there the line was just coming outside the door a little so we didn't expect much of a wait, but when we got there their was no wait. We were seated almost immediately at the front counter. I got the banana split hot cakes while my dad had the Pittsburg slam. My food was delicious, my dad also enjoyed his meal. The only thing that I could see as a problem is that a party of 3 or more would have to wait a while for seating.

Ok, I'll admit that I came here because I hear it's the official breakfast spot for the Obamas.  It was just after I grabbed a spot at the counter that I realized it wasn't.  It's fine, I was a bit hungover from a wild Friday night so a diner breakfast was just what the doctor ordered.

Service was fine, but the food wasn't particularly memorable.  I would never spend 20+ minutes in line waiting for a spot.  Ordered a omelette, which was massive, but I prefer diced veggies, and theirs were sliced and overly saut√©ed.

I also think the prices are a bit high for the quality.  $14 for omelet and OJ is what it costs for my favorite diner in SF.

Food is good. The place is very clean. However, customer service is lacking. I was trying to pay my bill and the lady told me it will be a second. She finished cashing out someone and then walked away and started getting people coffee etc. Very rude.

Have been Pittsburgh for almost 4 years now and have passed here many times, impressed with the line on the weekend. Finally went and I'm clueless as to why the line is so long, aside from the many options on the menu. I got an omelette and my dining partner got some eggs with bacon and potatoes. Both dishes were ok, but they're nothing that I can't make at home with groceries from the Strip. Service was efficient and payment is cash only (PNC location within like 100 ft of the restaurant).

So before visiting Pittsburgh, I asked friends from the area where I needed to go for food. And DeLuca's Diner on the Strip was recommended. Naturally since Sunday was nicer out than on Saturday, that area was not favorable for parking. So we saw that a second location was open about 20+minutes out. Sweet, so we made our was to this location under the thought that we'd have no problems. I wish I had a crystal ball, hell I would've settled for a magic 8 ball. 

We go inside and there are two other couples waiting. Cool no problem. The wait was barely five minutes. Get seated in a booth. Great! Look over the menu. Order a Large orange juice. The server comes back we place our order. I order the California Benedict, and then the other order was the Omelette Special. Alright, Simple enough!

Then I start observing. The booth next to us, a party of five, seemed to get there orders, but not at the same time, and the timing between their orders being delivered was staggered at best. This seemed troubling, but I kept observing. At one point one of the bidders was sweeping near us and made some loud comment about how he "needed to get paid." Um awkward. Oh look another plate came for the party of five, still three more to go. Needless to say it took awhile for them to get their orders. This continued to be unsettling. Then I overhear the booth behind me, their server apologized, and told them that she'd give them a discount for the inconvenient wait time. Wow, that's cool. The whole time we waited, we never once were visited by our server, given an update on the order. No offer of coffee. Almost 45min goes by and we get our food. 45 minutes, and it was close to closing time. 

Food arrives. And presentation was .......lacking at best. My home fries looked different from those on the other plate. My overall plate just wasn't great. The omelette was burnt. Like making an omelette should be apart of Breakfast 101. Cooking multiple orders shouldn't be rocket science, contrary to the outer space mural on the wall. 

When it came time to pay. We asked if we could leave the tip with the cashier. She said to just leave it on the table, well the table was already being bussed, and after the busser made that comment, we weren't exactly jumping to drop it on the table. 

Maybe it's a locals favorite, maybe the original spot is better. But I wouldn't waste the time going here again if I'm back in Pittsburgh. Service is key, even if thevwait is horrendous.

My friend took me here, after months of us meaning to try it. 

The location is in a plaza (near IKEA), but the old timey diner makes you feel like you've stepped back into time. The dining furniture was worn, but clean. Very vintage.

The waitress was annoyed we didn't know what we wanted to eat within 2 minutes. She gave us coffee and warm cream, but never asked if we wanted a refill. Our food came our fast and the order was accurate. My eggs were very oily/buttery so I only ate one yolk (over easy), it was cold. My pancakes looked great, but were flavorless. It was the first time I thought "did I just order lumpy, mushy flour for food?". I ate most of the topping, but was underwhelmed. My friend enjoyed her meal, so I pretended that I had eaten earlier. The waitress didn't ask how my food was, so I didn't say anything. 

Afterward, I grabbed something from Starbucks since I was still hungry.

Make reservations to avoid the line. But even with a line, they turn tables quick. My 20 minute wait was worth it. 

Ambience: First this is your classic greasy spoon diner and dive kind of place. It is not fancy. It is classic. 

Service: nice, courteous, and efficient. I watched them systematically clean up, re-seat, and keep it moving. Their hustle and bustle is an art in itself.  But for them to be as attentive, letting us know the status of the table, just kept sort of checking up with us as we stood there, it was pretty impressive... Then our Waitress was smiling thru my kids changing their minds and all their city slicker requests for this and that on the side. Appreciated her patience... She checked up during meal at the right times. And she had a quick chat with us before she handed the check over. She was just real nice.... Some of the best restaurants in the world could learn from this pretty humble easygoing waitstaff. 

Food: it was everything you expected, wanted and more. Everything was pretty much perfect for a diner. Waffles were fluffy and perfectly cooked. Home fries were delicious. And their version of eggs Benedict was amazing. 

Verdict: 5 stars for it's perfectly classic meal and for its reasonable prices.

We had been wanting to try Deluca's since they opened. Today we got our chance. It was a complete disappointment. We ordered the mixed grill, vegetables were steamed and tasteless.  We also ordered a breakfast burrito with chorizo sausage. It was overcooked and almost inedible. We also got the chicken fried chicken, eggs, and biscuits which was the only saving grace to the meal. I believe our first time at Deluca's will be our last. There are too many other better choices in Robinson to waste money there again. What a disappointment.

Came here for breakfast and it did not disappoint. Had to wait about 20 minutes for a table on a Sunday morning. The food portions were generous. I had a Nutella/banana crepe, which had a full banana stuffed inside it. Everything I saw come out to nearby tables looked delicious. Reasonable prices and friendly service.

My dad & I walked from downtown Pittsburgh because we heard Deluca's had the best breakfast in Pittsburgh. When we got there, the line was out the door. After 20 minutes, we got a table. It was a small little diner, but the food was very good. I got French toast & bacon. My dad got a ham & cheese omelet. We were both pleased with our meals & left full. We will definitely be going back when we return to Pittsburgh.

DeLuca's is a real Pittsburgh gem. Expect a line if you come here on the weekends, unless you are a very early riser! Last time I came was on a Friday around 9:00 am. By 10:00 am, there was a line out the door and that is pretty typical for this place.

DeLuca's walls are covered in Pittsburgh history, making wait for your breakfast not so bad! The diner is also a lot bigger than expected, it goes back pretty far. Do not expect servers that want to chat with you- this is a BUSY breakfast spot! Never the less, the service has always been great when I have visited. 

My boyfriend and I love this place and have been here so many times, but my parents have never been until I brought them here last month! They were SO impressed by the huge portions they received and loved everything. My dad had the Steel City Breakfast Of Champs, which consisted of a Short stack of pancakes, 2 eggs, 2 pcs of bacon, sausage, homefries & toast (mancini's toast to be exact). He loved everything and was really impressed with the pancakes! They were perfectly fluffy and just delicious. I had the hotcake special and loved every minute of it. They made my egg whites perfectly and the bacon was super good! My mom had an omelette and loved it as well! I've also had their specialty pumpkin pancakes and they are insanely good as well!

If you have never been to DeLuca's, you need to right now. Genuine Pittsburgh breakfast and you will leave full and VERY happy!
Hands down the best breakfast place in the Burgh!  You will wait in line and you will not regret the wait.  Try the eggs benedict!

Pamela's gets way too much credit in this town.  Deluca's, located in the heart of the strip district, is a daytime only diner with no frills, just the freshest, most delicious breakfast you can get in the city.  It's on my list of places I miss in Pittsburgh.

Breakfast is by far my favorite meal of the day. Some days I like it so much that I eat it twice (not at the same time, well mostly). So please understand that my rating is serious! as a serious breakfast connoisseur. Deluca's gets hype because it's awesome. It's not fancy. but it is some serious down to earth good breakfast foods. no pomp, no circumstance. just food. and a good amount of it also. I can often be found here eating eggs benedict, with reckless abandon, a big grin on my face, and a side of bacon well done. 

Favorite foods:
Greek Eggs benedict! steak tomato and feta? INSANE.
Seafood benedict! equally insane
Any of their pancakes (I don't even like pancakes, but I like theirs)

There is some times a wait, but they really do their best to keep it moving, and the staff are all super nice and speedy at getting you your future food coma. I'm not a fan of their coffee (read my reviews about my coffee snobbery elsewhere) but it will get the job done, eyes bright and alert! - their proximity to 21st street coffee as well as all of the other wonderful places in the strip makes a visit here a great start to all days that end in Y. 

They are cash only but there is a PNC ATM 2-3 doors down. I'm a repeat customer, a fan, and I'm sure you will be too.

I love good breakfast, authentic eateries, and a wild environment; and, Deluca's has it all. It's no surprise that one can wait up to an hour in a line snaking down the block for a table on Saturday or Sunday morning.

While my friend Chris and Callen were waiting in line for Pens tickets, I decided to hit up the Strip District and check out this breakfast institution. It's been featured on the Travel and Food networks, and I knew I was in store for something special. There was a huge line of people waiting in freezing weather. Since I was alone, I decided to try and skip the huge line and nab a seat at the bar, which was a stellar idea.

The service here was great. Although everyone working here was buzzing around at incredible speeds, they still regularly checked in on me. After I ordered my food, it came out quickly and I had my refills of coffee. The atmosphere here is my favorite part. A long, counter bar runs the length of the establishment. Behind it are cooks hard at work on equipment that must be at least fifty years old. It it's not broken, don't fix it! I was also in the back, in full veiw of a wipeboard that helps employees keep track of everything. They needed to order five box of coffee and also didn't want employees to forget the holiday bowling party.  Simply put: this place is fun.

The coffee is whatever, not bad, not great. For the food, I knew as soon as my eyes set on it: MOAB, or mother of all burritos. This was a huge soft tortilla filled with chorizo, scrambled eggs, hot banana peppers, tomatoes, onions, avocado and homefries. It's topped with salsa, cheddar and sour cream. Overall, delicious. There's a lot of flavors going on, but I really enjoyed this, and it was certainly filling enough to keep me going until dinner. Deluca's doesn't use the best ingredients, and it wasn't the most delicious breakfast, but I really enjoyed my visit. I'd go again.

Bottom Line: Enjoy the show by sitting at the bar. Marvel at the staff, and soak up the atmosphere. The food's not bad either. Cash only.

You can overlook a lot of things when the food is good however the food was terrible. Our waiter was under the influence of something  and high. The place is kind of dirty. They have a box fan hanging from the ceiling as a "ceiling fan". We are from our of town and travel often (on average 12days a month) and use Yelp as a guide to great food. Unfortunately this is not it. Oh and there was a 30-45 min line outside that we waited in just to have terrible service and mediocre at best food.
This has been the worst customer service I've ever encountered! I don't care if you're busy, you can still be nice to your paying customers! Not worth the wait.

Came here for Sunday brunch with a large group if friends. Our wait was somewhere between 30-45 min and we were hungry!! Only made me that more excited to try this place as we were from out of town. My boyfriend ordered the country fried steak and I ordered the French toast. We both really enjoyed our meals and this concluded our weekend trip to Pittsburgh beautifully. I would definitely return next time I'm in the Pittsburgh area.
Giant portions. Fast and furious service. Good value.  A really fun diner experience.

You'd have a better breakfast at Pamela's or Kelly O's. It is definitely not worth the wait in line. The employees are very miserable, except for the young boy at the register. Food is decent, if you don't mind employees poking their fingers in your food without gloves. They just can't seem to get the orders right. Walk the extra block or two, for a better breakfast all around.

This is what I consider the quintessential American diner. 4 stars for the food and 1 star for the authentic experience. 

- Capital D diner food: Lots of butter, bacon, and carbs
- Great old-school booths and counter to sit on
- Breakfast hits it out of the park in classic diner fashion
- Food comes out quick
- Free coffee refills

Easy beats Pamela's. On the food front there about toe-to-toe, but this place wins on the experience. If you're in town for just a few days, this is definitely one of the places to check out.

its hard to screw up breakfast they did it.... when ya tote a sign that says Pittsburgh's best breakfast back it up... thats why it got 1 star.

i dont understand the hype the lines the waiting when there are a ton of other places in town that blow this place out of the water.... ritters, pamelas etc etc. the bacon was soggy  euuugh. the coffee was luke warm potatoes/homefries bland.service poor at best.

dont waste your time or money on this place.

I stopped by DeLuca's yesterday with CM for brunch at around 11am.  Initially, I tried to call and make a reservation, but they told me that they only accept reservations for parties of at least 5.  However, they also told me that business was a bit slower than usual yesterday.  I believe CM and I waited about 20-30 min. to be seated.  Neither of us had been before, despite having lived in PGH for 3.5 and 1.5 years, respectively.

For my entree, I debated between the fancy french toast and a heavenly pancake sundae, but I ultimately decided on the latter, due to the recommendations of other Yelpers and its Man vs. Food fame.  Despite not being someone who's super into apple pie, I decided to get the apple cinnamon roll pancakes, again due to others' recommendations.  When it came out, it looked impressive, and when I dug in, I was quite pleased with it.  The warmth of the canned apples complimented the cool creaminess of the ice cream perfectly, with the zest of the cinnamon taking it to another level.  Despite being an apple pie naysayer, this dish was delicious!  Obviously, it was very sweet, so if you're not into sweet breakfast foods, you may want to order something else.  CM was less adventurous than me and went with the short stack of pancakes with bacon.  I tried a bite of the bacon, and it was very crispy and minimally greasy, and was bursting with the smoked savoriness of well-made bacon.  This was certainly basic diner breakfast fare, perfected.

What impresses me about DeLuca's is the breadth and interesting options of the menu.  Although they have all of the usual breakfast standbys, they also have a variety of creative options for the more adventurously-minded, such as the heavenly pancake sundaes and the fancy french toast.  They also have some interesting options on the savory side, too, such as the bionic omelette.  Speaking of which, I love the sci fi-themed names that they give the items (out-of-this-world omelettes, sonic sides, etc.).  My only caveat is that if you're trying to eat on the healthier side, there aren't many options in that vein here.  (I'd recommend the Square Cafe in Regent Square for a more health-conscious breakfast.)

Despite the slight annoyances of the wait and the cash only policy, I'd recommend DeLuca's over Pamela's for a quintessential Pittsburgh breakfast--though I do enjoy Pamela's crepes.  Needless to say, it's a strong contender for one of the best traditional breakfasts in PGH.  Do your visiting friends a favor and be sure to take them here for a hearty meal before browsing the Strip or visiting Heinz History Center!
Great omelets. Huge serving sizes. A real classic. But bring cash! No cards accepted.

Passed through Pittsburg today, I really wanted to go to the original in the strip district, however, traveling with a 4 year old and new born, and with the parking issues in the strip district we opted for their other location near the mall in park manor.  My son and, I split the banana praline pancakes topped with ice cream and whip cream.  First of all the pancakes by themselves tasted like a doughnut or a cake.  Than you add the pralines and bananas along with some kind of rum, and you get a masterpiece.  The pancakes reminded a little bit of a banana foster.  We ordered a side of eggs and bacon and both were a cut above the rest, not your typical bacon and eggs.

My wife and mother and law ordered the seafood paradise crepe, and the seafood omelette.  Both came with a cheesy hollandaise that was absolutely delicious.  Both came with langostino's, shrimp, and lump crab meat.  Everyone absolutely loved their meal.  Would absolutely come back here if, I lived here and, I cannot say that about too many breakfast places.

We stopped here before heading to Pittsburgh International Airport. I had a veggie wrap with chipotle pesto. It was really good.

Also, I approached the waitress with a special request and even though she mentioned that they usually do not do special things she was able to surprise us all with something special for my fiance's birthday.
